ags:resource.dc:title: Plants as tools for control and remediation of the environment polluted by organochlorine toxicants.

dc:description.dcterms:abstract: The influence of different concentrations of organochlorine pesticides on growing parameters and induction of detoxification enzymes of some agricultural annual plants has been investigated. As a result, the resistant and sensitive plants to organochlorine pesticides have been revealed. It has been shown that resistant plants are char- acterized by induction of detoxification enzymes such as peroxidase, phenoloxidase, cytochrome P450 containing monooxygenase and glutathione S-transferase. Apparently the tested pesticides undergo primary oxidation and subsequent conjugation of produced intermediates. According to obtained results it was concluded that degree of induction of above mentioned enzymes can be used as biochemical criteria for control and remediation of envi- ronment polluted by organochlorine toxicants.
